raw_text:
O'Gara revels in Ireland victory
 
 Ireland fly-half Ronan O'Gara hailed his side's 19-13 victory over England as a "special" win.
 
 The Munster number 10 kicked a total of 14 points, including two drop goals, to help keep alive their Grand Slam hopes. He told BBC Sport: "We made hard work of it but it's still special to beat England. "I had three chances to win the game but didn't. We have work to do after this but we never take a victory over England lightly." Ireland hooker Shane Byrne echoed O'Gara's comments but admitted the game had been England's best outing in the Six Nations. Byrne said: "It was a really, really hard game but from one to 15 in our team we worked really, really hard. "We just had to stick to our defensive pattern, trust ourselves and trust those around us. All round it was fantastic." Ireland captain Brian O'Driscoll, who scored his side's only try, said: "We are delighted, we felt if we performed well then we would win but with England also having played very well it makes it all the sweeter. "We did get the bounce of the ball and some days that happens and you've just got to jump on the back of it."
 
 Ireland coach Eddie O'Sullivan was surprised that England coach Andy Robinson said he was certain Mark Cueto was onside for a disallowed try just before the break. "Andy was sitting two yards from me and I couldn't see whether he was offside or not so I don't know how Andy could have known," said O'Sullivan.
 
 "What I do know is that England played well and when that happens it makes a very good victory for us. "We had to defend for long periods and that is all good for the confidence of the team. "I think our try was very well worked, it was a gem, as good a try as we have scored for a while." O'Sullivan also rejected Robinson's contention England dominated the forward play. "I think we lost one lineout and they lost four or five so I don't know how that adds up to domination," he said. O'Driscoll also insisted Ireland were happy to handle the pressure of being considered favourites to win the Six Nations title. "This season for the first time we have been able to play with the favourites' tag," he said. "Hopefully we have proved that today and can continue to keep doing so. "As for my try it was a move we had worked on all week. There was a bit of magic from Geordan Murphy and it was a great break from Denis Hickie."
llama3.2:1b: Ireland won 19-13 against England in the Six Nations, with Ronan O'Gara scoring 14 points including two drop goals. The team's captain Brian O'Driscoll said they performed well despite playing well by their opponents and were happy to handle being considered favourites to win the title. Ireland coach Eddie O'Sullivan rejected claims that Mark Cueto was onside for a disallowed try, instead stating that England played well and dominated certain aspects of the game but lost in others.
llama3.2:3b: Ireland defeated England 19-13 in the Six Nations, with Ronan O'Gara scoring 14 points including two drop goals. The victory is seen as "special" despite hard work by both teams. Ireland coach Eddie O'Sullivan and captain Brian O'Driscoll praised their team's performance, saying they had worked well together to secure the win. England coach Andy Robinson disputed a disallowed try and claimed England dominated forward play, but O'Sullivan rejected this assertion citing several lost lineouts on both sides.
gemma2:2b:
Ronan O'Gara scored 14 points for Ireland, who won 19-13 against England in a hard-fought match.  Ireland's win keeps their Grand Slam hopes alive. Shane Byrne and Brian O'Driscoll agreed the victory was special, with O'Driscoll scoring the only try and acknowledging England's strong performance.  
 Eddie O'Sullivan praised his team for their defense and lauded Ireland's well-worked try. 
 He also refuted Andy Robinson's claim about England dominating in the forward play. 
 Brian O'Driscoll also noted that Ireland embraced being considered favorites for the Six Nations title.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Ireland defeated England 19-13, keeping their chance of winning the Six Nations at bay with Ronan O'Gara's remarkable performance. The Irish side showed some resilience in the final match against England while acknowledging that this victory is special to them. Brian O'Driscoll scored the only goal for Ireland but said it was a good win after the best game he has played this season. Eddie O'Sullivan suggested Andy Robinson had likely known Mark Cueto was onside, which could have been an advantage. O'Driscoll defended well against England's playmaking and insisted they were able to handle pressure of being considered favourites. The Irish coach is confident that Ireland can continue their dominance in the Six Nations title chase.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Ireland's 19-13 victory over England, despite being considered favorites, is hailed as a special win due to O'Gara's strong performances and the difficult nature of their defense. The team worked hard defensively but conceded some penalties. Ireland coach Eddie O'Sullivan criticized Andy Robinson for asserting that Cueto was offside, stating he couldn't see it at distance. Both players emphasized their teams' efforts throughout the game.
qwen2.5:3b: Ronan O'Gara hailed Ireland's 19-13 victory over England as special, with his 14-point haul including two drop goals crucial to the win. Byrne praised the hard work shown by the team, while captain Brian O'Driscoll expressed delight despite the close game. O'Sullivan contested Andy Robinson's claims of dominance and supported Ireland's performance, stressing their try was well worked and a highlight of the season. O'Driscoll highlighted Geordan Murphy and Denis Hickie's teamwork for his try.
opencoder:1.5b:
O'Gara revels in Ireland's victory with a 19-13 defeat to England, which signifies a special performance. Despite England's impressive game at the Six Nations, O'Gara had made hard work of it but its defeat was a tribute to England’s best performance. He had three chances and despite the defeat, it's still special to beat England.

Ireland's hooker Shane Byrne played an engaging role in the game with his comments but admitted that the game had been England's best outcome. The game was marked by a combination of hard work, trust in those around us, defensive pattern, and an all-around fantastic performance.

England’s coach Eddie O'Sullivan was pleased to see Ireland's coach Andy Robinson saying he might have expected Mark Cueto to be onside for a disallowed try before the break. However, this uncertainty did not affect Ireland’s ability to win the game, which continues to give it a compelling reason.

Ireland's captain Brian O'Driscoll scored his side's only try and hailed the victory without any defensive challenge. Despite England’s impressive forward play, Ireland was pleased with the absence of them as favourites for the Six Nations title.

Ireland's coach allowed Ireland to handle the pressure of being considered favourites to win the Six Nations title. Despite England's dominance in the forward play, it would have been less favourable if they were dominant.

The game marked a remarkable progression of O'Gara's confidence and resilience, which is all that is needed for a successful victory at the Six Nations. The effort, hard work and trust brought about a remarkable and special outcome, marking an era where excellence is celebrated as well.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary is concise, preserving the key ideas and details of the original text while omitting unnecessary information such as explanations, formatting, and reasoning processes. The main points that are preserved in the summary include:

1. The Irish victory over England: O'Gara's statement that Ireland won the game "happily" and "specially" is preserved.
2. The significance of the win: The text highlights the importance of the win for Ireland, emphasizing it as a special achievement that will be remembered for years to come.
3. The role of O'Driscoll: The statement that O'Driscoll was surprised by England's comment about Cueto being onside is preserved.
4. The team's confidence: The text emphasizes the Irish team's confidence in their ability to win, with O'Sullivan saying "we did get the bounce of the ball and some days that happens and you've just got to jump on the back of it."
5. The commentary from Robinson: The statement that England played well is preserved, as well as the comment that they dominated the forward play.
6. The Irish team's handling of the pressure: The text highlights the Irish team's ability to handle the pressure of being considered favorites to win the Six Nations title, with O'Sullivan saying "hopefully we have proved that today and can continue to keep doing so."

tinyllama:1.1b: O'Gara revels in Ireland victory and hails special win over England, while Byrnne echoes O'Gara's sentiment and praises his team for sticking to their game plan. Meanwhile, O'Sullivan dismisses any notion that England dominated the forward play and emphasizes that Ireland had a chance to keep winning despite facing pressure due to their perceived favoritism in the Six Nations title race. O'Drscoll also expresses satisfaction at handling the pressure of being considered favorites and hopes for another win against Wales next week.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Ireland 19-13 victory over England in the Six Nations rugby match took place at Lansdowne Field, Belfast, on Saturday, February 8th, 2016. The Irish team displayed exceptional teamwork and determination as they managed to overcome England in a high-tempo game that saw both sides showcase their skills and tactics. O'Gara's performance was particularly noteworthy, as he kicked a total of 14 points, including two drop goals, to keep alive his side's Grand Slam hopes.
phi:2.7b: Ireland's fly-half Ronan O'Gara celebrated his team's victory over England in the Six Nations, calling it "special". The Munster player scored two drop goals to help keep the Grand Slam hopes alive. Shane Byrne, who echoed O'Gara's comments, admitted that it was England's best performance so far in the tournament. Despite their loss, Ireland captain Brian O'Driscoll praised his team's defensive efforts and said they were delighted with their performance. Coach Eddie O'Sullivan disagreed with England coach Andy Robinson's assertion about a disallowed try, saying he couldn't see whether Cueto was offside or not. He also dismissed the idea that England dominated the forward play and pointed out that Ireland lost one lineout while England lost four or five. Despite being the favourites for the Six Nations title, Ireland acknowledged the pressure of playing against top-ranked teams like England. They believe they have proven themselves today and can continue to do so in future games. O'Gara's try was a result of weeks of practice, with Geordan Murphy providing a great break from Denis Hickie's defense.

Eddie O'Sullivan praised England's performance and rejected Andy Robinson's claim that Mark Cueto was onside for a disallowed try just before the break.
